SENT.plain: Current consensus on the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) includes cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) in the form of exposure and response prevention (ERP)
However, the generalizability of these methods to elderly populations remains largely undocumented
This clinical case study examines the effectiveness of medications and intensive, inpatient ERP in an elderly patient with onset of OCD following basal ganglia infarcts

There was a dramatic reduction from baseline to follow-up in both obsessions and compulsions with Yale-Brown Obsessive-Compulsive Scale [YBOCS; Goodman et al., 1989] total scores decreasing by over 20 points
These gains were maintained up to 1 year post-treatment
Age-specific issues and the application of standard therapeutic methods to elderly clients are discussed
